text: TITLE: Althorp Estate, 1774 Two servants knock in four flag posts, with fifty paces i between. They are marking out a race track of some kind. We’re on the back lawn of a beautiful country house. Off the distance are fields filled with sheep, long grass and trees. It’s a perfect summer’s day with birds singing and gentle breeze rustling in leaves. Six ARISTOCRATIC YOUNG MEN stand in a group on the field. They are preparing for a running race: taking their jacke off and laying them down, then rolling up their sleeves. On the lawn, a similar sized group of ARISTOCRATIC YOUNG WOMEN stand across from them. Behind is a tent and a tabl with the remains of an outdoor picnic. To one side of the women a young, beautiful and content GEORGIANA approaches with a hat. Inside are folded up pieces of paper which she mixes around. She offers the ha to the women and they each pick a piece of paper. One aft another they read out the names of the men opposite who look over and smile. GEORGIANA is left with the last name and looks up.
(Loudly) You'd better not let me down, Charles Grey. I’ve got twenty guineas riding on you. A young man, CHARLES GREY looks back. He is quick to repl

Only twenty? I’d double that if I were you. GEORGIANA smiles, while the look on Grey’s face suggests that he’s taking this very seriously. He joins the other men in the starting line up, who also seem pretty intent winning.

Are you ready gentlemen? Twice around the track. On my count, three...two...one...go! GEORGIANA drops a handkerchief. The men immediately sprin out across the park. The women start to cheer. GEORGIANA shouts the loudest, then starts to jump up and down.
Come on Grey, come on!

In CLOSE UP, a quill pen dips into an ink well and starts to write on a virgin piece of white paper, ‘The Fourteent Day of May, Seventeen Hundred and Seventy Four...’ HEATON, a solicitor, is at a table writing this document, his ink pen scraping against the paper. Around him, the room has the atmosphere of a serious occasion: still and dark although the sun shines brightly outside and the voices of the women - especially GEORGIANA - bleed throug The DUKE, HEATON’s employer, is standing at the library window, looking into the garden at GEORGIANA cheering on the young men. The scene is distorted through the wavy glass window pane: a beautiful and mildly surreal image. LADY SPENCER is seated behind the DUKE, perched on the ed of a large sofa, with LORD SPENCER behind her. She tries ignore the muted screams of her daughter in the backgroun

(Cautiously) I trust your Grace still finds Georgiana an attractive girl? The DUKE turns and we now see his face properly. He is handsome, older than GEORGIANA, and has a rakish twinkle his eye. He looks at LADY SPENCER enigmatically.
Of course, Lady Spencer. Another of GEORGIANA’s shouts audibly registers. LADY SPENCER starts to pour tea from a silver Samovar in front of her in an effort to drown out the noise.
She is well-bred and devoted to her duties. She speaks French, Latin and Italian, and is fully versed in horsemanship and dancing...
Yes, I am aware of all that. She is a credit to you.
--.-I can't think of anything in her that would stand in the way of a singularly happy marriage - The DUKE turns for a brief moment and smiles inscrutably LADY SPENCER. HEATON cuts to the chase.
These are not the issues that burden the Duke, Lady Spencer. It is His Grace’s duty to produce an heir. On the other hand, your daughter may expect a handsome reward when that occurs -—
Thank you, Heaton.

(resuming his writing) Your Grace ... The DUKE remains looking out of the window, not so much o of interest in GEORGIANA, but rather because he finds the pre-nuptial proceedings uncomfortable. LADY SPENCER throw a brief glance at LORD SPENCER, who seems disinclined to discuss these matters. She resolutely turns to the DUKE.

Your Grace can rest assured. The women in our family have never forfeited on that account. LADY SPENCER smiles at her husband who nods back. HEATON looks to the DUKE for confirmation, then decides to addre his comment to no one in particular.
Well with that assurance... HEATON turns the document around toward the others for th to look at. The DUKE smiles at them, then turns and fastidiously removes a spot on the window pane.
So be it, then.
The men are running back. GREY is in the lead.

Come on Grey! GREY puts his head down and accelerates. He wins, totally out of breath and sweating. All the others follow, similarly exhausted and bent over double. GEORGIANA turns to the other women, a book containing all the bets they’ve laid in her hand.

(Charming smile) I do apologise ladies but it appears my horse has won. The young women smile, and gather around GEORGIANA. GREY approaches from behind, still slightly out of breath, man and athletic. GEORGIANA turns to him.
Well done Mr Grey. He looks intensely at her, bravely standing much closer than may normally be expected. Some of the young people notice this, and there’s an edge of tension at this risqu behaviour.
(Plirtatiously) And my reward? GEORGIANA returns the look.
What would you suggest? The young people - eavesdropping on this conversation - smile and look at each other. GREY is just about to come back with a reply when...
Your mother wishes to see you Lady Georgiana.  4aAk GEORGIANA curtsies to GREY who bows in return before GEORGIANA runs off. GREY watches her go.
INT. ALTHORP. DAY 4aA LADY SPENCER waits inside. GEORGIANA enters.
I must apologize Mama, were we making too much noise?

Not at all, darling. We have much more important things to talk of. Come here. GEORGIANA waits expectantly for an explanation. LADY SPENCER reveals nothing, holding in her secret, but her excitement can’t help but shine through.
I have heard a rumour... LADY SPENCER pauses for dramatic effect.
Yes...?
...that I shall very soon be addressing my daughter as Her Grace, the Duchess of Devonshire. GEORGIANA is taken wholly by surprise.
Is it true, Mama?
(Proudly) It is.
...the Duke of Devonshire ...
I had hoped not to part with you until 18 at the soonest, but with such a fine match it would be selfish of me not to let you go.  4aB
He loves me?
Yes, of course.
(Excited) I have met him only twice.
When one truly loves someone, one doesn't have to know them well to be certain, Georgiana. One feels it right away. [Pause] I do believe you will be happy with him.
I know I shall, Mama...I know I shall.

EXT. ALTHORP. DAY 4aB GEORGIANA walks out onto the balcony and looks into the garden. The young people are chatting and eating. GREY, however, is to one side, looking out across the fields. GEORGIANA takes a moment to herself. In the last light of day, sun rays illuminate pollen in the air around her. Th camera moves in to a CLOSE UP of her optimistic face.
OMITTED 4n

CLOSE UP of GEORGIANA’S face, same framing as before, but now heavily made up and in her BRIDAL DRESS. Wedding musi plays as she is walking forward down the aisle, in this relatively small and intimate space. At the far end stand a select group of powerful and important ARISTOCRATS. As GEORGIANA passes LADY SPENCER, her mother looks incredibly proud. When GEORGIANA reaches THE DUKE, he looks composed. She smiles at him. Credits are superimposed throughout this sequence, until the main title appears as GEORGIANA stands at the front:
The music stops. The PRIEST steps up to begin the service

EXT. DUKE’S GILT COACH. LONDON STREET - DAY 9 It’s a wide and busy London street. There are ORDINARY PEOPLE on the side of it, TRAFFIC kicking up dust. It’s a messy mass of noise and smells, smoke and dirt. Through the middle of this comes the DUKE’S GILT COACH followed by two other COACHES, in stark contrast to their surroundings. Heads turn to look at this eighteenth centu motorcade, people wave, children start to run after it.

INT. DUKE’S GILT COACH. LONDON STREET - DAY 9A Still in her wedding dress, GEORGIANA sits alongside the DUKE in his CARRIAGE. The DUKE has his curtains closed around him to shield him from public view, although GEORGIANA is staring intently at the PEOPLE outside. There’s an awkward silence. Finally,
What do they want?
To see me. And my new wife, of course.
Oh.

It’s a damn nuisance, but you’1l get used to it. GEORGIANA, however, smiles and gives a little wave: she doesn’t mind at all. A bit further down this street the CARRIAGE nears a set o massive gates where a large group of THE GENERAL PUBLIC c be seen waiting and waving outside.
Here we are. The carriage begins to turn.

The CARRIAGE turns off the street and through the massive gateway. The gates are locked behind them. Inside the huge courtyard Devonshire House is revealed as an oversized, stark and austere building. A wall runs all the way around it, blocking the view and completes the foreboding sense of arriving in a prison. The FOOTMAN ope GEORGIANA’s carriage door. GEORGIANA steps out into this hugely intimidating space. Flags bearing the Duke’s crest blow in the wind, making a tense and aggressive sound. She stops a moment to take it all in. BURLEIGH, the HEAD BUTLER steps forward.
Welcome, Your Grace. BURLEIGH then leads her toward rows of HOUSEHOLD SERVANTS who are formally lined up to greet her. They bow and curt as GEORGIANA walks past.
Your Grace.
Your Grace. GEORGIANA looks up to find the DUKE has disappeared insid
GEORGIANA enters a massive marbled ENTRANCE HALL. The DUK stands at the top of the staircase, with his two dogs either side of him.
This way.

GEORGIANA stands in front of the DUKE. He takes a pair of scissors and cuts through the stitching of her wedding dress, letting it fall to the floor. She smiles at him, a bit nervous. He proceeds to remove the rest of her underclothes, a pile growing around her ankles.
You're in safe hands. His attempt to reassure her only serves to unnerve GEORGI more. She remains standing and looks up at the ceiling, w the DUKE expertly unlaces her corset.
For the life of me I don't understand why women's attire must be so damned complicated.
I suppose it's just our way of expressing ourselves.
Whatever do you mean?
Well, that you have so many ways of expressing yourselves, whereas we must make do with our hats and our dresses, I suppose.

Hmmm. The corset falls to the floor. The DUKE then removes GEORGIANA’S chemise. Suddenly, she is completely naked. S sends the DUKE an uneasy look. For a moment he appears to be lost in his thoughts, just staring at her.
Is something the matter?

No, not in the least. Go to the bed, please. GEORGIANA goes to the bed. The DUKE starts to undress. Around him the faces of his forefathers bear down from th massive portraits on the walls of his bedroom.  12 13 14 The DUKE, now naked, walks over to the bed and stands before her. The camera is behind the DUKE and focussed on GEORGIANA: having never seen a penis before let alone an erect one, she is intently and nervously staring at his.

(Bending down) Kiss me. GEORGIANA finally kisses him, inexpertly. He lies down on of and penetrates her, the look on her face suggesting th is an extremely new and strange experience. The DUKE begi to move rhythmically while GEORGIANA still tries to make sense of the whole thing - all the time watched intensely from the walls by dozens of his male ancestors’ eyes.

GEORGIANA sits looking isolated and lonely in a huge gilt edged blue room. She is trying to read a book but her concentration continues to be interrupted by the presence of MALE FOOTMEN stationed at two of the doors, like sentries. She turns a page and tries to focus but fails. A TALL SERVANT enters. GEORGIANA puts the book down.
Lady Spencer, Your Grace. GEORGIANA looks up, relieved, to see her mother enter. HEATON bows and walks away across the vast space.
GEORGIANA sits with LADY SPENCER. They are playing cards with real money laid out in front of them - and talking.
...One has to accept one's responsibility, my darling. Certain obligations come with marriage, no matter how burdensome they may seem.
Yes, but when we are together, intimately, I mean, he...
I know; it can be a bother. However, it is only until you have given him a son. The occasions will then become fewer, and less...determined. Lady Spencer places down a card.
I think it would feel different if he might talk to me every once ina while. It’s not that he’s unkind but he never talks to me.

Well, perhaps you ought to talk less. I fear I may have given you a little too much education. You make tiring conversation and ask questions which a man is disinclined to answer. GEORGIANA looks at her mother in resignation. How can any have too much education?
Learning these things takes time, too. Marriage is just like languages or music or painting. It requires a long apprenticeship.

Yes. But he is... he is not at all as when I first met him. I thought he would be like Papa. Under his cool reserve I would find a wealth of depth and sentiment. But he doesn’t seem interested in anything. Apart from his dogs.
Try not to be too hard on His Grace, G. He is merely intent on fulfilling his duty. As for talking to him - whatever is there to talk about, my dear?
No, you're right. How foolish of me to think that I should be able to converse with my husband. LADY SPENCER sighs and looks at her spirited daughter.  15

Georgiana, equip yourself with patience, fortitude and resignation. A boy will come soon enough, then you'll see. GEORGIANA nods. She sends her mother a polite little smil then lays down a winning card and scoops the pile of mone toward her.

A great, noisy dinner party. WHIGS in full gala, among which is CHARLES FOX, a stout little man making a speech the grand room. Everybody listens to him. HEATON watches from the side. GEORGIANA is by his side, her attire conspicuously more daring than before. She looks apprehensive: she is the on woman in a room dominated by alcohol and testosterone- fuelled MEN, one of whom is relieving himself into a chamber pot at the side of the room. GEORGIANA, though, pays attention to FOX. The DUKE, at the other end of the table, does not.

«+-a political party, in my definition, consists of men of honour, entertaining similar principles that may be more successfully pursued by the force of mutual support and, not to forget, the unfailing generosity of his Grace the Duke of Devonshire. Everybody looks to the DUKE, applauding loudly and somewh sycophantically. The DUKE nods cordially.

So between the persistence of my own humble self... Everybody laughs again, including GEORGIANA, thus betrayi that nobody finds Fox humble. FOX, pleased with the succe of his joke, joins in the laughter.

I say, between my persistence and the Duke's purse, we must always remember the honourable and principle aims of the Whig party, aims that some consider radical but which, to us, seem simply just and right and sensible. (MORE)

Just to bring independence to America. Right to end the slave trade. And sensible to pursue freedom for the common man, so that the blessings of this blessed plot, this England, may be more equally enjoyed - by all of its inhabitants. All these are greeted by ‘hear hears’ from the room, and deep thoughtfulness from GEORGIANA.

And so - having kept everyone from the burgundy long enough - let me propose a toast to our host and benefactor his Grace, the Duke, and his beautiful new Duchess. They all shout "hear, hear", reach for their glasses and toast in the direction of the DUKE. He nods cordially bac FOX sits down at GEORGIANA's side. The murmur of small ta rises as the guests carry on with their eating and drinki A MACARONI on the other side of FOX compliments his speec
Excellent speech, Mr. Fox, splendid.
I thank you. However, it is always easy to address a congregation of friends, and even more so when those friends are drunk. The MACARONI and GEORGIANA smile.
How did the Duchess find Mr. Fox's speech?

I must confess I am not yet at ease with political speeches. Their very form tends to obstruct my view to their actual meaning - if such there be. FOX, expecting inane flattery, is surprised, although favourably impressed by GEORGIANA's candour. The MACARONI not observing that GEORGIANA has earned FOX's undivided attention, proceeds to think that he is still part of the conversation:
(Ingratiatingly) I myself found it very rousing... FOX ignores him. He knows who he wants to talk to.
In which particular section of the speech did the message elude your Grace?
Well, I have great sympathy with your sentiments in general, but fail fully to comprehend how far we - the Whig party, that is - are fully committed to the concept of freedom.
We would like to see the vote extended...
To all men...?
Heavens no. But certainly to more men. Freedom, in moderation.
"Freedom in moderation"?
(Pleased with himself) Precisely. GEORGIANA nods, then smiles faintly, but mischievously.

I am sure you are full of the best intentions, Mr. Fox, but I dare say I would not spend my vote - assuming I had it - on so vague a statement. Either one is free or one is not. The concept of freedom is an absolute. After all, one cannot be moderately dead, moderately loved, or moderately free. It must always remain a matter of either or. Fox smiles at GEORGIANA in surprise.  16

(Cheeky ) It is no wonder you are having such problems at the ballot box. GEORGIANA smiles, winningly. Fox scrutinizes her face, no a little shocked but clearly impressed. Another well-dressed MAN taps his glass and rises to spea The room falls silent.

I think it's appropriate to say a few words... The DUKE seems in no mood for another speech, and resolut gets up and leaves. The entire company, including the MAN about to make a speech, look bewildered at one another. GEORGIANA, too, is surprised and doesn’t really know what she should do, so she stands too and goes after the DUKE.
The DUKE is in the middle of a corridor, where he has sto to talk to a YOUNG MAID. GEORGIANA exits the room behind trying to catch up.
Your Grace? The DUKE turns and looks at GEORGIANA. The YOUNG MAID curtsies and exits.
Is anything the matter?
No...
You just left?
Well... I had done eating. And those damn speeches bore me to distraction. We have to ban them in the future.
But you are the Whigs main supporter...  17
I have no problem with politics, it’s the rhetoric I can’t stand. The DUKE turns back and continues down the corridor.
Shall I come with you?
Not at all, why ever should you? The DUKE turns and leaves. GEORGIANA looks at him, bemuse

The conversation has stopped, everyone fearful their benefactor is aggrieved for some reason. The whole table men watch as GEORGIANA sits back down, looking to her for reassurance. She addresses the room.
The Duke is fine. He simply wants to rest a while. People don’t look convinced.
Was it the length of the speech that got the better of the Duke?

(To the room) Certainly not. He enjoyed it immensely and expressed a hope that next time it would be even longer. All the men laugh. Fox sends her a look and raises his gl to her. She smiles back at them all, reaches out for a dr raises it back to FOX and takes a long swig.

Late night, and all the guests have left. BURLEIGH overse as a team of SERVANTS are clearing up the mess: extinguishing the candles on the huge candelabra, on thei hands and knees scraping food under the table etc.

GEORGIANA passes quietly down the long candlelit corridor and of this massive house. She is happy, buoyant, tipsy. GEORGIANA walks towards their bedroom. Suddenly a door op and the YOUNG MAID the DUKE was talking to earlier comes running out, half naked, carrying her clothes in her arms She looks at GEORGIANA in alarm, and runs off. GEORGIANA looks at her, shocked and speechless, as she disappears off into the darkness of the corridor. Georgia turns and proceeds toward the bedroom.
In the bedroom the DUKE is sitting half naked on the bed. GEORGIANA stops at a distance.
What is going on?
About what? GEORGIANA approaches, unnerved.
What have you been doing?
Nothing to concern you. He smiles at her, kisses her.
Wait, William. I don’t understand...
What is there to understand? GEORGIANA is lost for words.  21 22 23
You look very beautiful tonight. Fascinating fabric. Is this dress your design?
Yes it is. Thank you.
Then allow me to appreciate it in more detail. The DUKE kisses her breasts and proceeds to remove her clothes. GEORGIANA, with a desire to do the right thing, acquiesces.
Time has passed. Months. The season has changed from summ to autumn, with wind in the trees and leaves on the groun which workmen are busy collecting.

GEORGIANA and the DUKE sit together in a gigantic dining room at a very long table. In the corner a musician quiet plays the harpsichord providing a low background ambience SERVANTS discreetly serving food and wine. GEORGIANA and the DUKE eat in silence. After a few moments BURLEIGH emerges to whisper something into the ear of the DUKE. He understands the message and nods.
Send them in... BURLEIGH exits. GEORGIANA looks at him.
(Lighting up) Are we having company? Is it Fox? The DUKE chews his food and swallows before he replies.
Don't you think this mutton has a funny taste?
Not really, no...
Well, I do... HEATON enters with a NANNY holding a little three-year-ol girl, CHARLOTTE, by the hand. The girl is very nervous. T DUKE looks at them, then at GEORGIANA.
This is Charlotte. She will be staying with us. GEORGIANA looks at the little girl who remains absolutely still. Then she looks at the DUKE.
Why...? The DUKE signals to the BUTLER that they can leave the ro upon which the BUTLER leads the NANNY and Charlotte out.
Because her mother is dead. She has no other place to go. GEORGIANA looks in disbelief at the DUKE. The penny drops
Have you fathered that child?

It's only a little girl, Georgiana, hardly the end of the world. The DUKE sends a suspicious look at the mutton before him looks up again, only to find that GEORGIANA is still star at him. He takes a tiny bite of the mutton, examining its taste as if he suspected poison, during which he continue
I am pregnant with your child. Surely you are not expecting me to look after her?

We have a house full of vacant rooms, G. She need not trouble you. As a matter of fact, she may even be of use; you can practice your motherhood on her... (gesturing at her stomach) ++.until our son arrives. GEORGIANA hands move protectively toward her stomach to reveal she is midway through pregnancy. She looks at him, silently furious and hurt.
This certainly doesn't taste like normal mutton. I am sure something is the matter with it.  24
The DUKE pushes his plate away and smiles at her. A SERVA immediately steps forward to take the plate away.

GEORGIANA walking past, pauses outside the room in which nanny is putting CHARLOTTE to bed for the night. She hear sobbing coming from inside. GEORGIANA is moved by this bu steals herself against the painful sound and walks off. After a few paces she stops.
The little girl is lying on the bed, the NANNY trying to comfort her.
Would you leave us, please.
Your Grace, I didn't see you. The NANNY looks nervously at GEORGIANA, not knowing wheth she ought to leave.

...leave us, please... The NANNY scurries out of the room. GEORGIANA sits down o CHARLOTTE's bed. CHARLOTTE is hiding her face, still sobb She reaches for her doll, as if it was threatened by GEORGIANA's presence and she means to rescue it.
(Softly) I am Georgiana. What's your name? CHARLOTTE makes no reply. GEORGIANA smiles at her. She ca see that she is trembling and gently puts her hand on her shoulder to calm her.
Shh, there now, you are safe here «..SO what do you call your doll? No answer.
Surely, it must have a name. Every doll must have a name.  CHARLOTTE stares at her in silence.  25

Let us make a deal, then. Tonight you decide on a name for your doll. You may choose between any in the whole wide world, and then, in the morning, you tell me which one you've picked. Charlotte nods slowly. GEORGIANA rises and turns to leave
Alice. GEORGIANA turns back to Charlotte and smiles.
Good night then Alice. And good night Charlotte.
It's snowing outside and GUESTS arrive in fur coats.

MUSICIANS are playing in the foyer. GEORGIANA - dressed amazingly - receives people with smil and poses as a newspaper sketcher draws her from the corn of the hall. Her belly is gigantic - she is in the very l stage of pregnancy. FOX arrives with the flushed and flas RICHARD SHERIDAN. He looks at her.
An inch more, and I do believe your Grace will explode.
Sheridan certainly knows how to pay a compliment. GEORGIANA smiles.
There are still a few more weeks to wait.
A huge belly has never been more becoming on anyone.  26
And Fox here offers an expert opinion, seeing, as he does, a giant belly every time he passes a mirror. GEORGIANA smiles. SHERIDAN leans against FOX in affected confidentiality.
If your belly were on a woman, we'd all know what to think. FOX leans against SHERIDAN in imitation of his act.
My dear Sheridan, less than an hour ago, my belly was on a woman - so now what do you think? GEORGIANA delights in the risky repartee.
That will teach you to insult Mr Fox before the gaming has begun.

The ballroom has been converted into a gaming area with a series of round card tables and is full of GAMBLERS. It h a decadent, opulent and smoky atmosphere. The DUKE is at one table while GEORGIANA sits at another with SHERIDAN to one side and FOX to the other. The conversation runs fast and easy.
Her Grace wins again. GEORGIANA pulls in her chips.
Another wager?
I’m out. My funds have run dry and I’ve no one left to borrow from.
Maybe it would be different if people thought you had the slightest intention of paying them back?  27
One should never give money to one’s creditors, dear boy. It only encourages them.
Is there no one in London not in debt?
Just the poor. They all laugh loudly. Suddenly GEORGIANA stiffens as she feels a sharp pain. She gasps and looks at them in alarm.
Are you all right?
Yes... She doesn’t look convinced. Another dart of pain. GEORGIA is in anguish.
I would like to... Another shooting pain. By now, FOX, SHERIDAN, and several the other guests have jumped to their feet to help her ou The DUKE notices the turmoil from his table.
Are those labour pains? My wife is in labour! The DUKE now raises his glass and addresses the guests. H looks genuinely excited.

I think this calls for a toast. I may have an heir before the night is out. He toasts. EVERYBODY joins in the toast and some cheer, s those who are helping GEORGIANA out of the room. The last image is of the DUKE, happy and proud.
The house is quiet. LADY SPENCER hurries inside.

LADY SPENCER steps into the room, still dressed in her ca A SERVANT follows her and receives her cape. She is surpr by the sight in front of her: the DUKE is throwing a ball exercise his dogs who scamper around the ballroom.
Your Grace —
I'm in no mood for conversation, I'm afraid.
But, pray tell, is my daughter -
Is your daughter at all able to give me a son? Beat, as LADY SPENCER takes in the situation and quickly contemplates her response.
Take heart, your Grace. As long as the mother is in good health, consider this mishap a draft, a promise of what is soon to come. In our family -

Yes, yes - LADY SPENCER stops as the DUKE waves her away, in a gestu which roughly signals that the DUKE appreciates her effor to comfort him, but is too troubled to talk. LADY SPENCER smiles politely and leaves.
(muttering) Hell and damnation ... The DUKE throws the ball deep into the room, his dogs racing to retrieve it.

GEORGIANA is sitting by the cot, totally engrossed with h new baby, stroking its arm, staring at its face. A wind u MUSIC BOX is playing nearby. LADY SPENCER enters the room. Georgiana looks up and smiles.
Darling, how are you?
Quite well. LADY SPENCER sends her a warm smile and steps up to look the baby sleeping in GEORGIANA's arms.
.and is she strong and healthy? GEORGIANA nods and smiles.
She is perfect. LADY SPENCER smiles and looks at the girl.
She is her mother’s likeness... GEORGIANA smiles as she looks down at the baby with her mother. Then her mind shifts, and her expression becomes darker. There is an edge to her tone.
Did William receive you?
Yes.
Was he upset that it wasn't a son? He just glanced at her briefly and left. I’ve hardly seen him since.
It's been a difficult time for His Grace, my dear. Many eyes are upon him, not all of them kind. LADY SPENCER senses the tension and looks back at the bab keen to change the subject.
Why, she's the loveliest... The baby starts to wake up, hungry and crying.
Nurse... Lady Spencer gestures to the WET NURSE to come forward which she does, unbuttoning her shirt to feed.
(Firmly) No, I will do it, thank you. The wet nurse looks to Lady Spencer.
Darling, are you sure...?  30 31 32

Yes, I am her mother after all. Even if she is only a girl. Georgiana is already starting to feed her hungry baby fro her breast, a picture of earthy motherhood in stark contrast to the pomp of her surroundings. LADY SPENCER looks over at this headstrong young woman, n a little bit worried.
A very wide shot of the empty English countryside, with t train of GILT COACHES mid-frame, glinting in the sunshine TWO MORE COACHES follow, laden with STAFF and LUGGAGE.

Close up on the face of a three year old girl, HARRYO, sitting in a GILT COACH. HARRYO sits next to CHARLOTTE, n aged 10, and G (4). GEORGIANA - now four years older - si opposite. She is sketching dress designs while the childr play with cards. In the second COACH the DUKE sits alone and in silence - bar his dogs - staring out of the windows at the passing countryside. A newspaper sits besides him with a story about Georgiana on the front page. He has also aged four years.
The COACHES go past the Royal Crescent. On the grass in t foreground lots of people are strolling, having picnics, children play.
THE FIRST COACH stops in front of a MASSIVE VILLA. SERVAN jump down to open the door of the COACH.
The FOYER alone is fabulous, spacious, sparkling. The DUK surveys the place. Finally he sighs, as if it's a bad mot

Well. It'll have to do. It's only for a month. The DUKE goes o.s. GEORGIANA enters, accompanied by the children, and soon after by SERVANTS carrying masses of luggage: suitcases, hatboxes, shoeboxes etc. LITTLE G watches them go past.
If we’re only here for a month, Mama, why do you have so many cases?
(Smiling, ironic) A lady needs a change of clothes, my darling. LITTLE G smile back.
Now, who will get the best bedroom? GEORGIANA looks to her CHILDREN. They run into the house full of excitement and energy, with their mother hot on their heels.
There's a massive ball inside, all guests in formal clothes. Leading Whig JAMES HARE addresses the crowd from the balcony.

It is always a delight, when one is on holiday, to request a few words of wisdom. So without further ado it is a great honour to hand over to our most distinguished guest... We see the faces of the DUKE and GEORGIANA standing in th darkness of the wings behind HARE. Who is he referring to

When she appears, every eye is turned towards her; when absent, she is the subject of universal conversation; and what we see her wearing tonight, I look forward to seeing the rest of you wearing tomorrow... The DUKE’s face seems to sink.

...the Empress of Fashion herself ...The Duchess of Devonshire. The CROWD applaud loudly. GEORGIANA enters, accompanied b the DUKE. There’s a hushed ‘wow’ as everyone takes in her extraordinary appearance: she wears a HUGE, THREE FOOT ADORNED WIG with OSTRICH FEATHERS inserted into it. She b at the crowd, the total centre of attention. The DUKE loo uncomfortable next to her.
We come away to Bath to get away from London and all of London has come away to Bath. EVERYONE laughs. The DUKE forces a smile.
I always appreciate the Honourable Mr Hares' introductions. He has a jeweller's wit; (MORE)
whenever he turns a phrase, one finds another facet.  42 There are chuckles from the CROWD. GEORGIANA, looking confident, strokes the feather in her hair.

And as he suggests, somebody did indeed ask me earlier what kind of feather it is I’m wearing. Well, only two specimens of this rare bird are known to man. One of them has clearly ended up on top of my head. The other, rumour has it, is running for office in the Tory party. There is great laughter. GEORGIANA looks to the side of t room and sees that the DUKE has caught the eye of a young blushing BEAUTY. She smiles at him.

HIGH TEMPO MUSIC is being played by some MUSICIANS. Many people are dancing energetically on the floor - especiall GEORGIANA who is in the middle of a group of admirers: on high and basking in the attention. GEORGIANA is an expert dancer, moving from one male partn to the next. The CAMERA follows the feather on her head standing high over everyone as she twirls around the room like a sharks fin jutting out above the water line.  43 44 All eyes are upon her: COURT REPORTERS in the corner try sketch it; men look on from the sides with barely disguis sexual interest; women look at her dress, the feather, an then their husbands’ reactions. The DUKE, however, stands at the side, pretending only to be half-watching. GEORGIANA is spurred on by his indifference, and as the dancing progresses, she begins t show off and flirt in inverse proportion to it. GEORGIANA then loses herself in the dancing until...She glances up to see the DUKE talking to another prey - a beautiful young woman in a dark dress, BESS FOSTER. GEORGIANA now sees BESS evidently rejecting the ducal overtures and leaving the room. Rejection is a new experi for the DUKE, and he is appropriately taken aback, as is GEORGIANA. The DUKE's eyes stay on BESS as she leaves int the next room. GEORGIANA stops dancing.
(To her partner) Excuse me... GEORGIANA turns and walks away from the DANCERS.

head_text.subj: INT. BATH ASSEMBLY ROOMS. OCTAGON ROOM. NIGHT

text: BESS is helping herself to some food from the sideboard. She is about to take a bite of a tart when she sees GEORGIANA, staring.
I don't believe we have been formally introduced?
I haven't, at any rate. Lady Elizabeth Foster. They greet each other.
I saw you talking with my husband. GEORGIANA looks at BESS in a levelled way. BESS returns t look.
Yes, he wished to dance.
That is not usually considered his forte. And you declined?
I'm ill at ease with male company for the moment. GEORGIANA smiles. BESS smiles back at her. GEORGIANA look at BESS, sizing up this beautiful girl with great interes Beat.
What brings you to Bath? BESS takes a moment to consider how she will answer this.
My husband, Mr. Foster, is enjoying his mistress in Bournemouth, and I wanted some diversion. And you?
(hedges ) The Duke is taking the waters for his gout... Beat. BESS looks as if to say, ‘carry on’.
...and I...for my health. BESS is upset that GEORGIANA has not rewarded her honesty with similar directness.
Really? (imitating gossip) "The Duchess of D., married how- many-years and still no son and heir." GEORGIANA is taken aback, hurt. BESS immediately realises regrets what she’s said.
I beg your pardon. That was an awful thing to say.
But it is the truth, at least. They look at each other. Something passes between them.  GEORGIANA lowers her voice in a conspiratorial way. It’s almost as if they are flirting with each other.
Although I had hoped to avoid being reminded of that. If only for this evening.
Trust me to say something silly. I always do, you know.

Then perhaps you should have accepted the Duke's invitation. You have much in common. BESS does not know if she is allowed to laugh. She looks GEORGIANA and smiles. Then they both laugh. There is a re connection here, two lost people who have found each othe The DUKE enters the room.
Well... Home, I think. Georgiana. GEORGIANA and BESS look at him as he leaves. Then GEORGIA gets up.
Where are you staying?
I've rented some rooms in town.
We must meet again.
We must.
The DUKE’s carriage trundles down the Royal Crescent.

The DUKE sits on the seat. GEORGIANA, however, has to sit on the floor to make room for the ostrich feather that’s still on top of her head. They are not looking at each other and the strain of thei relationship shows on them both. We remain on GEORGIANA’S face as the bright sounds of young children’s voices fade up until we...

EXT. BATH PARK — DAY 47 GEORGIANA, a NANNY flanking her, is playing chase and running races with her children in the sunshine. It’s fre and easy and everyone is laughing and having a good time. GEORGIANA steps back to watch the three girls run off and gets her breath back. HARRYO runs and falls. GEORGIANA ru up to comfort her. HARRYO runs off again and GEORGIANA watches her go.
Up and fall down, up and fall down. GEORGIANA turns to see BESS standing behind her.
Why can’t we recover like that?
Too far to fall now. They smile.
Hello again.
Hello. [Beat] Your girls are lovely.
Thank you. Do you have any children?
I do. Three boys...
Three boys ... What the Duke wouldn't give for one of them. BESS smiles.
She looks least like you, your eldest.
Yes. (Makes a decision) I'm sure you know the story. GEORGIANA looks at BESS. BESS does, but she doesn't speak
My husband's daughter was born before we married. The mother was a maid. The maid died; we took the child.
I'm sorry, I shouldn't have spoken.
Never mind. It's the worst kept secret in London. She's nine years old now.
And...do you love her?
Of course I do. The same as all my children. They are the world to me. BESS smiles, but behind it her own pain shows through.

49k INT. BATH. PRIVATE BATHS. DAY - LATER 49k GEORGIANA and BESS come out onto a balcony with tables, benches and chairs. Below and beyond it is a manicured garden with people strolling, pushing wheelchairs etc. It has the feel of an upmarket sanatorium. GEORGIANA walks to a small drinking fountain and stops to sip a cup of hot liquid. BESS takes a sniff and recoils.
Thermal water. It’s the sulphur that makes it smell so bad.
And you really have to drink it?
Twice a day for four weeks.
Do you have any reason to believe you cannot birth a male?

No. Except four miscarriages, two still births - both of which were sons - and two girls .. BESS feels for her, and smiles supportively. They make their way to a table and sit down. BESS looks around them people are stealing sneaky glances over at GEORGIANA.

Everybody's staring at you... GEORGIANA smiles at her cheekiness. BESS turns right arou to look in the direction of a couple staring at GEORGIANA As she does so GEORGIANA is able to see a DARK BRUISE on BESS’S NECK. GEORGIANA is shocked, and her hand instinctively reaches out to touch her.
What’s that on your neck? BESS is taken off guard. She looks a little vulnerable.
Bess...? BESS looks evenly at Georgiana, as if trying to decide to tell her something.
It’s not illegal for a man to beat his wife with a stick unless the stick is thicker than your thumb. GEORGIANA is speechless.
Mr Foster? But - he can't do that...
Considering what else he's done to me, that's not the worst...  50
What could possibly be worse...?
He's taken my children. He won't let me see them.
What do you propose to do?

Really, I'm at my wits' end. I have made some sort of alliance with a man who will assist me in abducting them. What I'll do when he does, I don't know. Live under an assumed name, I suppose. The law supports Mr. Foster. GEORGIANA is lost in the horror of BESS’s situation.
And in the meantime, where shall you stay?
Continue lodging I suppose, until my money runs out.
Well, there at least, I think I can help. GEORGIANA reaches out to take another drink of water.
The DUKE - continuing the previous scene’s action - picks up a glass and drinks. Georgiana, Bess and the Duke eat. Georgiana and Bess exchange secret glances.
William? We leave tomorrow. And Lady Elizabeth is not due to meet her parents on the continent for some time. And she hardly visits London at all.
Ah. Pity that.  51 52 53
You see she doesn’t have a place to stay.
Oh dear, problem there. BESS and GEORGIANA hold their breath. The DUKE glances up
Well why doesn’t she stay with us? For a while at least. Georgiana and Bess grin like schoolgirls.
GEORGIANA leads the way down the corridor. BESS follows, gazing at the house, marvelling at the grandiosity of it all. Unlike GEORGIANA’s first arrival it feels informal, free, excited.
This is incredible ... GEORGIANA, tickled to have BESS with her, takes her arm.  54 55

(Ironically) Yes. There’s the castle in Ireland, Bolton Abbey, Chiswick, Burlington - and Chatsworth, of course, which is much bigger - but this is more like home. BESS laughs. GEORGIANA leads her through more rooms. GEORGIANA opens a door to reveal a beautiful bedroom with adjacent dressing area. BESS is suitably impressed. They laugh and hug each other close.
I am so glad you are here. (Devilish) I have arranged a wonderful start to the season.

It's OPENING NIGHT. A HUGE CRUSH of SOCIAL TYPES are in t theatre. Many of the women have their hair piled high wit an ostrich feather in it. They hold programmes that read ‘School For Scandal’ by Richard Sheridan. JOURNALISTS and CARTOONISTS sit off to the side, like paparazzi, sketching. We see glimpses of their renditions In them, GEORGIANA's large wig looks even larger. ON STAGE the performance is in full flow: an argument between "Sir Peter Teazle" and "Lady Teazle." The actors are made-up and costumed to look suspiciously like GEORGIANA and The DUKE, and the set is a replica in miniature of the Devonshire House living room.
“Lady Teazle, Lady Teazle, I’1l not bear it!”
“Sir Peter, Sir Peter, you may bear it or not as you please; but I ought to have my own way in everything.”
“Lady Teazle, though my life may be made unhappy by your temper, I‘’1l not be ruined by your extravagance.”

“My extravagance! I’m sure I am not more extravagant than a woman of fashion ought to be.” IN THEIR BOX the DUKE and GEORGIANA look on, stiff and v separate. BESS sits behind them. There’s a very tense air the DUKE is looking mortified while GEORGIANA seems to kn exactly what’s going on. She looks down at SHERIDAN sitti in the front row, who looks back equally knowingly, and winks at him.
“May all the plagues of marriage be doubled on me, if ever I try to be friends with you any more!”
"So much the better"
"No, no madam.: ‘tis evident you never cared a pin for me, and I was a madman to marry you."
“And I am sure I was a fool to marry you - an old dangling bachelor... The camera moves into the DUKE. He endures the humiliatio with a straight face but his insides are in knots.

...-who was single at fifty, only because he never could meet with anyone who could have him.” The audience LAUGH LOUDLY and look up to where the DUKE a GEORGIANA are sitting. The DUKE grips his seat.
Very well, madam! Very well! A separate maintenance as soon as you please. Yes, madam, or a divorce!”

(Triumphant ) “Agreed! Agreed!” The audience laugh and cheer. Amid the noise, GEORGIANA looks across the theatre to see the reaction. She sees a handsome YOUNG MAN in his 20s. S looks back to the stage, but the YOUNG MAN remains gazing at her. She looks back, realising who it is - CHARLES GRE Unlike the crowd, he is not laughing at all.
After the show: close up on champagne cork popping and champagne poured into glasses. The DUKE is skulking aroun the edge of the crowd. GEORGIANA and BESS meet with FOX. 56
Bess. This is Mr. Fox. The Leader of the Opposition. Mr Fox, Lady Elizabeth Foster. BESS is impressed. They nod at each other. CHARLES GREY approaches from behind FOX.
Ah. And here is my protegee, Charles Grey. BESS nods to both the men
Mr Grey.
Your Grace.

He’s our newest bright young man - scarcely out of Cambridge and already a member of Parliament. GEORGIANA can’t take her eyes off him. He looks at her to BESS notices this and quickly starts a conversation with FOX, leaving GEORGIANA to talk to GREY alone.
I always felt you would do well, Mr Grey.
Thank you.
Did you enjoy the play? GREY is uneasy, but still looks GEORGIANA straight in the eye as he replies.
I must confess I did not entirely. GEORGIANA is surprised.
I hope you haven’t lost your sense of humour since entering politics...
Not that I am aware.
Then you do realise ‘School For Scandal’ is written as a comedy?
Yes...although from where I sat it read as a tragedy. GEORGIANA is troubled. GREY’s unexpected comments affect her deeply. Just then SHERIDAN approaches with open arms.

Your Grace! How we've missed you! In your absence London has been reduced to the dreariest province! GEORGIANA smiles. She breaks her eyes from GREY'S and sha resumes her usually effortless social persona.
And this, of course, is the playwright, Mr. Sheridan. May I present the Lady Elizabeth. SHERIDAN greets BESS. Then, with an apologetic mien at th others, he pulls GEORGIANA away.

Pardon us. I do not mean to be rude, but I have an entire cast dying to meet the Duchess. I shall return her in a moment, promise. SHERIDAN and GEORGIANA leave. BESS watches GREY as GREY watches them go. She looks to the DUKE, who has found som consolation in the form of a gauche young GIRL.
GEORGIANA throws a look back to GREY, then SHERIDAN presents her to a lined-up CAST, who all curtsy and bow.
Were we fair on the Duke?

It could have been worse. (Whispers to her) My original title was "The Bad Marriage." SHERIDAN smiles. GEORGIANA does not. A SERVANT enters with a tray of drinks. Everybody helps themselves to one. SHERIDAN produces a bottle of opium.
Opium?

Just a drop... SHERIDAN pours opium in their drinks. A few of the actors actresses have a drop too. GREY takes this in as he watches the DUKE and then GEORGIANA. GEORGIANA turns and looks at him. For an extra beat.

INT. DEVONSHIRE HOUSE. GEORGIANA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 58 BESS and GEORGIANA are in nightclothes, sprawled across each other on the bed. They are intimate and relaxed, lik two teenage girls after a night’s clubbing.
Were you at all able to forget things and enjoy yourself?
It was a wonderful distraction, thank you.
Good.
I talked all night to Mister Grey...
Oh yes?
He is in love with you. GEORGIANA laughs.
My dear Bess. No he’s not. In fact I fear the very opposite. GEORGIANA looks at her, thinks. BESS smiles.
Can't you tell by the way he looks at you? Honestly, can't you tell?
Stop it, please.
Georgiana. Procreation is not just about offspring. In fact, it can be quite nice.
(laughs uncertainly, lies) Yes, I know...
Try to close your eyes ... and envision Grey slowly opening your dress ... and kissing your back. GEORGIANA starts to giggle.
Oh, please, they never do such things...
Oh yes they do. BESS gets up and lies behind GEORGIANA. GEORGIANA looks a little nervous about this.
Close your eyes...Grey is behind you....slowly opening your dress... BESS pulls back part of GEORGIANA’s clothing to reveal he shoulder. BESS begins to kiss it.
Bess, stop.

(Firmly) ...close your eyes....kissing your back... GEORGIANA relents and closes her eyes. BESS continues to kiss her back. Suddenly GEORGIANA goes silent, a look of real surprise on her face: she is experiencing sensations she never knew even existed. Bess continues, soft but in charge, as they both allow themselves to become lost in the erotically charged momen GEORGIANA lets out little gasps of pleasure... BESS pushes it further... Her hands explore under GEORGIANA’S nightclothes... Over her breasts... The tops of her legs... GEORGIANA gasps again, a realisation that parts of her bo could give such pleasure... BESS tugs GEORGIANA’S hair back a little... Her hands reach further... GEORGIANA closes her eyes...

(Whispers) There...see... BESS stops what she’s doing. Beat. They both breathe heavily, the sexual tension and arousal hanging heavy in the air. They are a little embarrassed, scared even of wh might happen if they carried on, and for a moment it seem that is what they might well do... But BESS gets up and walks to the window as GEORGIANA readjusts her clothes. They regain composure and try to carry on as if nothing has really happened.

In the play this evening, there was a scene in which Lady Teazle and Mr. Surface discuss their affair. They acknowledge that once a lady of quality has provided her husband with a son then she may take a lover. GEORGIANA takes it in.  59 60 61

Be ready, dear G, when the time comes. GEORGIANA lies back on the bed, eyes wide open, thinking. This image is held as the sound of a haunting operatic voice - accompanied by harpsichord - starts over it and carries us into the next scene.

We are in the grounds of a huge country house and its estate. SWARMS of COUNTRY PEOPLE, MEN on HORSES and TENAN are present, with others arriving all the time. Massive amounts of food are laid out on trestle tables with a ten for the gentry on the other side. The singing and harpsichord continue, and we find that AN OPERA singer and HARPSICHORD perform to a grand outdoor picnic. We see the DUKE and BESS standing together. FOX and GREY at the rear of the audience, looking on. GEORGIANA is with her children, working her way through t ORDINARY PEOPLE and TENANTS, making them feel welcome. Th respond with reverence. She walks up to LADY SPENCER and embraces her.
Hello Mama.
(Coolly) Hello my dear. BESS comes over too.
We’re so glad you were able to visit, Lady Spencer.  LADY SPENCER looks hurt.
Are ‘we’ really?
Yes, G speaks of you all the time.
Well that is nice to hear. My daughter’s letters have become so short of late that finally they do not exist at all.
I do apologise Mama. It is merely a reflection of my current state of happiness...
(Cutting across) I only know what she is up to by reading the Morning Post. GEORGIANA is stung by this. The DUKE wanders up behind, surveying the scene.
And how long do you intend to stay on Lady Elizabeth?
Please, ‘Bess’. I don’t know. I’m sure I’ve worn out my welcome already.
Nonsense.

Lady Elizabeth is free to stay with us for as long as she likes. LADY SPENCER is left open-mouthed, a little alarmed at ho close they all seem. The music has stopped and everyone turn and politely applaud the musicians. FOX and some WHI come forward. GEORGIANA turns and smiles broadly at them.
Who let these radicals through the gates of Chatsworth?  62
No one lets us in anywhere! That's why we’re radicals!

The DUKE performs his duty talking with the important people in the tent: other aristocrats, politicians and wealthy businessmen. FOX, SHERIDAN and GREY are here too. GEORGIANA is opposite, amongst the ORDINARY PEOPLE, where she is carrying food to their tables and making sure they are being well looked after.
What a fine spread. GEORGIANA turns to see GREY behind her, coming over from the tent.
Thank you. We do our best. GEORGIANA starts to walk through the tables with a plate food. He follows.
We? From what I hear you run these open days single-handedly.
Well, the Duke does find inviting all and sundry to the house a little... testing. But it’s only once a week.
The Duke would prefer his tenants to starve?
It is his property.
Then he must surely embrace the responsibilities that come with it. Or perhaps His Grace would prefer instead to be divested of such troublesome possessions.
(Provocatively) What an interesting idea.  63 GREY, encouraged by her double meaning, continues.
You know, I despise the fact that so few men can have such precious things - and that they mismanage them so appallingly. GEORGIANA smiles at him. She knows he is talking about he
And what would you suggest? He returns her smile, remembering the exchange from years ago.
That people should be set free.
And will freedom alone make them happy?

The point is not to make people happy. The point is to make them free, so they can pursue their own idea of happiness...whatever that may be. GEORGIANA looks impressed. She realizes how close they're standing, and in full view of the PEOPLE. She moves away few feet.
I must get another plate.. GEORGIANA walks off. GREY watches her go, happy in the knowledge he has made an impact. He starts back toward FO and SHERIDAN.

It is toward the end of the day. The sun is casting long shadows on the lawn as the picnic is being packed up. GEORGIANA leans against a low wall, sipping a cordial, al the while watching GREY in conversation with some men. BE approaches GEORGIANA.
Whatever is the matter with you? Your behaviour is so out of the ordinary.

I just feel like keeping to myself today... BESS sits down beside her, leaning close and intimate. Th look at the men, GREY at the centre, then look at each other. BESS smiles broadly. GEORGIANA blushes.  64 BESS digs GEORGIANA playfully and gently in the ribs. The giggle like schoolgirls. GEORGIANA looks up to see LADY SPENCER is watching, a disapproving expression on her face.
LADY SPENCER and GEORGIANA are walking through. Other GUESTS mill around.
(Hushed) But you have only known her three months!
Bess is my friend! She is the very best of women.
She seems to be many things, but I would be hard pushed to say she were that.

It may pain you to recognise it Mama, but a great change has come over my life and its name is Lady Elizabeth Foster...about whom it can be truly said I have at long last found my other self. LADY SPENCER’s pulse races. She wants to interject.
I understand if that may make you feel a little jealous. LADY SPENCER stops.
(Fierce whisper) This is a dangerous path to choose my girl.
I am not a girl, mother, I am the Duchess of Devonshire. It would serve you well to remember that.
Yes, and you have begun to cavort so constantly in public you cannot live for your own soul. It is no surprise you are gathering weeds instead of flowers.
65 66 GEORGIANA is stunned, like a little girl cut dead by her mother for showing off. LADY SPENCER turns on her heels a walks off leaving GEORGIANA fuming inside.

GEORGIANA, a rebellious look on her face, takes a drink from a BUTLER. She then heads toward GREY who is among a group of MEN. As he sees GEORGIANA he excuses himself fro the conversation and meets her.
Your Grace...
Mr Grey, I have been thinking. The national election is in six weeks, yes? How is the campaign going?
Terribly. Our only hope is to save Westminster for Fox. GEORGIANA smiles. There’s a mischievous sparkle in her ey
I have many faults as you well know, not least among them is my ability to draw attention. Perhaps we could use that to our advantage...

GEORGIANA stands on a platform dressed in the most outrageous costume yet, her hair piled three foot high above her head and decorated with Whig-coloured ribbons. In front is a HUGE CROWD noisy: a massive mix of people from drunks and prostitutes to lords and ladies. Banners proclaim WHIGS, VOTE FOX. JOURNALISTS mill around, scribbling into notebooks and sketching GEORGIANA. In the crowd, women are fanning themselves with fans bearing Georgiana’s likeness. It’s like a pop concert.
(Shouts to the crowd) Ladies and Gentlemen. (MORE)

I give you a man who will inform us of the work we must do and the party we so believe in! Mister Charles Grey! APPLAUSE as GREY moves to take the stage. GEORGIANA and GREY exchange a look as he positions himself.
I am here in Westminster to speak on behalf of our candidate Sir Charles James Fox... APPLAUSE.
Well, I wish only to address a single issue. Power. GEORGIANA looks at GREY, clearly proud of him.
The basis of power in our country is land, as it has been for centuries. And the aristocracy owns nearly all of it... There are a few laughs from the CROWD.

-.-along with all the places in the Government, control of the House of Commons, Ambassadors, Governors, Judges, and a host of other posts too numerous to mention. They maintain this influence by transferring their land intact, generation after generation. And in so doing continue to dominate English life. GREY stops to look at the faces of the PUBLIC looking bac at him. They are with him.
So, if we win this election, if we get the power we seek, what will we do with it? GREY’s listeners are quiet. GREY proceeds.

Will we merely follow in the footsteps of those that came before us? Master the art of compromise? Of postponing the greater good for the greater advantage? Will we do that? (Long pause) No. We won’t. Because we believe in the words we've spoken... A few scattered ‘hear hears’ begin.
+..and we have faith in the hearts we've stirred. More ‘HEAR HEARS’. GREY’s rhetoric takes flight.

The world is on the brink of disaster or salvation. From France to America, men and women are struggling to free themselves and find meaning in their existence. Change is upon us. Loud calls of ‘YES’ and applause.

We shall not return to the old ways! We shall not shirk our promises and our duties! We shall take England into this brave new world and shake the thunder from the skies! This we vow! APPLAUSE. CHEERS. GEORGIANA gazes at GREY. GREY looks at her, flushed and excited. She blushes like mad.
GREY stands alone. GEORGIANA approaches.
How did I do?
(Trying to hide her feelings) I think it was not an embarrassment.  Grey's face crumbles in disappointment. GEORGIANA grins.
It was a marvel. GREY smiles. A big open, boyish smile of relief.
But did you agree with what I said?
Every word. GREY gains self-confidence. He approaches GEORGIANA.
I was nervous. Your presence trebled the numbers at least. GREY is now very close indeed. GEORGIANA feels the effect of it. She becomes short of breath. GREY speaks softly.
I am nervous even now... GEORGIANA knows that she ought to keep a distance, but remains where she is.
So am I. There is tension in the air. A POLITICIAN walks past them They both acknowledge him as he goes. Then GEORGIANA star at GREY, and moves a little closer.
Do you think of me when we are not together?
(surprised) You ought to know I do... of you more than anything else.
You hesitated before replying ...

I am unused to being asked so directly, and by you of all people. GREY walks close. He very gently puts his hand on hers. S looks down at his hand, then up at him, blushing a little  68 69 70 71 72 73 74 75

(whispering) I think of you every day. They look lovingly at one another. GEORGIANA is just abou to reward GREY's candour with a confession of her feeling when the sight of SERVANT approaching brings her to remember herself. She withdraws her hand.
Your carriage awaits Your Grace. GREY nods. GEORGIANA starts to leave, her eyes remaining Grey until she turns a corner and is gone.
GEORGIANA enters. Silence. She races across, the soles of shoes echoing as she click-clacks across the vast space.
GEORGIANA makes her way quickly down the hall, her shoes still making that distinctive sound.

(Hushed whisper) Bess. As she approaches the door to BESS's room her pace slows two servants are listening outside it. GEORGIANA is perplexed. When they see her they stand back looking awkward. GEORGIANA continues walking toward them.

What are you doing outside Lady Elizabeth’s bedroom?  The servants don’t reply. GEORGIANA comes closer, then finally stops. Suddenly the noise of her shoes clicking on the floor is replaced by t muffled noise of BESS and the DUKE having sex: passionate energetic, enjoyable. For several painful, humiliating and shocked moments GEORGIANA is paralyzed in front of the servants. Then GEORGIANA backs away down the hall and is off.

GEORGIANA’S hat sits on a table, the ‘VOTE FOX’ sign clea visible on its side. GEORGIANA’S hand hangs down over a chair. THE DOOR opens and the DUKE enters, stealthily. The sun i just pouring GRAY LIGHT into the room. He closes the door very softly and then turns to see... GEORGIANA sitting on his bed. She looks ashen. They stare each other.
GEORGIANA paces. The DUKE sits on the bed, caught. It is difficult to see if he is actually ashamed, but he is listening patiently to GEORGIANA.

Of all the women in England, you had to throw yourself upon her. I have not objected once to any of your affairs, I have accepted whatever arrangement you have proposed, I have raised Charlotte as my own daughter, but this... I have one single thing of my own... why couldn't you let me keep Elizabeth for myself?
We see a worried BESS coming up the corridor outside GEORGIANA’s bedroom to find out what all the noise is abo
What kind of man are you?!
GEORGIANA is raging at him.
She is all I have to cling to! She is my sole comfort in our marriage. The DUKE patiently hears her out.
BESS's eyes are filled with tears.
You have robbed me of my only friend!
GEORGIANA pauses, nearly spent. Then she finally challeng the DUKE, more imploring than angry.
What is wrong with me? Why have you never loved me?!
(simple, exhausted clarity) I do not claim to be a man of fine sensibility, G, but I have always known what I expect from this marriage and what I am prepared to give. GEORGIANA doesn’t reply.
As a husband, I have fulfilled my obligations. As a wife, you have not.
She has to go! Now! She is never to set foot in this house again!
(Hackles rising) Do mind your temper, G. You are quite forgetting yourself.
I want her out! I never want to lay eyes on her again! Go down and tell her to leave at once!
I couldn't ask her that. I won't do it, G.
The door swings open - BESS jumps aside - and GEORGIANA comes crashing out of the sitting room, furious. GEORGIAN storms down the hall, followed by BESS.
Georgiana--!
You have taken yourself from me! You don't love me!
I do love you. Really I do.
No! Love is an act! It is more than words and undying oaths! It's what you do! I loved you! You only said you did. BESS is stung. Her eyes fill with tears.
Leave. Get out of this house! BESS remains standing, reaches out for GEORGIANA.
(breaks down, cries out) Get out!!! BESS leaves the room. GEORGIANA sinks slowly to the floor weeping, sobbing.
GEORGIANA sits, like a little girl, back at home. LADY SPENCER pours tea from a silver Samovar.
I did not like her from the first.
You've made that quite clear, Mama.
She is gone from Devonshire House, I hope. GEORGIANA looks away, ashamed. LADY SPENCER puts the Samovar down.
They're living there together? Georgiana, what have you permitted to happen?
I don’t know! Won't you please just help me! Tell me what to do, Mama! GEORGIANA hangs her head. LADY SPENCER surveys her daught and the mess she's in. Her demeanor softens.
You must write to your husband and insist he send her back to whatever horrid little place she came from.
He will not. It is out of the question, he says.

Then you must return and resume your duties. Make him realize whom he loves. You will give up your politics, your nights on the town, your gambling. For once you will devote yourself as a loving wife and settle down to the task at hand: providing him with an heir. And then he will soon tire of her. GEORGIANA looks at her mother with sadness.
You have no other option.
Seen from inside the house, GEORGIANA gets out of her carriage, observed by a couple of servants. She proceeds to the front door.
The DUKE awaits her just inside the door. He looks at her with worry.
Hello, G. ...
(Coldly) William. GEORGIANA walks straight past him and proceeds upstairs. At the top BESS meets her with an apologetic demeanour. GEORGIANA is cold as ice. She passes her without even a look.
INT. DEVONSHIRE HOUSE - GEORGIANA’S BEDROOM - LATER 87 BESS quietly enters GEORGIANA's room.
I may not have the authority to remove you from this house, but I can at least order you out of my room.
Won't you please let me explain? GEORGIANA becomes furious and shouts at BESS.

There is nothing to explain. I trusted you, I made you my confidante, and you repaid me by stealing what is mine. GEORGIANA turns her back and looks out of the window. BES approaches her carefully.  88
This is my only chance of ever seeing my children again. The Duke is the most powerful peer in England. He is my only chance. GEORGIANA turns to her.
There are limits to the sacrifices one makes to see one's children.
No, there aren't. No limits whatsoever. GEORGIANA takes in what she just said, before letting animosity get the better of her once again and turning aw

Get out of here. We have nothing more to say to one another. BESS leaves, closing the door silently behind her. GEORGIANA’s finger slowly pushes a perfume bottle off her dressing table until it falls and smashes on the floor. GEORGIANA hears the sound of carriages approaching. She gets up and goes to the window

The DUKE's CARRIAGE pulls up. AUGUSTUS, JOHN, and HARRY emerge from the carriage. BESS shrieks with joy and leaps out of the house. She run and hugs them, crying. It’s incredibly touching and GEORG is moved, despite herself.

GEORGIANA comes downstairs. Unseen, she looks into the ro and watches the DUKE getting AUGUSTUS a hunting rifle fro the wall. The DUKE appears surprisingly keen, gentle even He clearly relates to boys. To one side BESS holds a sleeping HARRY. GEORGIANA stares on in silence, understanding the DUKE an BESS in a way she has never done before. They look like a quiet, functional family unit. GEORGIANA quietly comes closer. The DUKE is now showing AUGUSTUS how to use the rifle.
.---hold it like that, Augustus, it won't come back at you.
Yes, I see.
Good. Your father doesn't hunt, I take it.
No.
Oh dear. Well, we can soon make up for that. AUGUSTUS smiles, as does BESS. The DUKE looks up, and see her approval does a rare thing: he smiles too. BESS gets and brings the DUKE a drink.
(Whispered gently) Thank you. The DUKE strokes her hand. GEORGIANA moves away and leave

It's a grey and drizzly day. The gardens are largely empt GREY'S carriage is parked by the roadside. COACHMEN wait beside it, informally leaning on the vehicle. A little further down the road, GEORGIANA’s carriage pulls up. In wide shot GEORGIANA, black cape with hood up, makes he way across the gardens.  Well away from the carriages and COACHMEN, GEORGIANA approaches GREY, who is waiting under the trees. GEORGIAN seems preoccupied. GREY, however, is simply excited about them meeting again.
(Hushed voice) Did you tell the Duke who you were meeting?
No.
Did he ask?
No. GREY pauses for a moment.
Good.
He has other things on his mind. GREY stops and scrutinises GEORGIANA. He can tell that sh is not truly present.
As do you. The direct recognition causes GEORGIANA to stop too, and then look away. She walks off in a different direction. GREY follows.
(Softer now) Would it help to unburden yourself? GEORGIANA sends him a little smile and a shake of the hea
It is nothing I can discuss with you. Besides, it would only bore.
You don't have to please others all the time.
I was brought up to. It's a difficult lesson to unlearn.
I believe you do it so that people will love you.
(looks deeply at him) What would make you think that?
From what I have seen. With your husband, your friends - especially Lady Bess. Even the public.
(looks away) I have never thought of it that way. You make me sound pitiable. GEORGIANA turns and walks away, upset. GREY realizes he h gone too far. He chases up with her.
I've gone beyond my brief. I apologize. Please believe it was only for your sake I spoke. GEORGIANA looks at him, and then carries on walking slowl thinking deeply. Grey moves closer to her again.
Please tell me what is wrong. She turns and looks at him intensely. The fountains in th pleasure garden dance in the background.
I fear I have done some things too late in life and some too early. They stare at each other a moment. The wind blows gently the leaves of the trees above them.
No, you haven't. Slowly, GREY moves to GEORGIANA. The air is thick. GREY g closer. They kiss. Not for long, but a gentle, warm kiss. Then he withdraws. GEORGIANA is blushing.  91
I have waited all my life for that kiss. GEORGIANA averts her eyes, and looks confused. He loses h composure a bit.
I'm sorry ...
No. It's... She looks up at him again.
I have never been kissed like that before. They stand and look at each other. Then they move closer, another kiss. Gentle. And longer, this time.
GEORGIANA is with BESS and the DUKE. She seems sober, together and strong: fortified. They sit opposite each ot at the table as if in negotiation. A long silence. Then:
All right. Beat. The DUKE looks at BESS. What does she mean?
"All right..?"
Do you love each other?
Georgiana -
Do you love Bess, Your Grace?
+». Well ... I... where is all this leading?
I make no demands on him.
...And Bess, you love my husband?
.».. As I do you. GEORGIANA nods, still not giving anything away.
You intend to stay here?
-.. William asked that I do. GEORGIANA nods.
And you couldn't find it in your heart to refuse him.
-.-No. BESS and the DUKE remain quiet. Beat.
Then let us make a deal.
A deal? Beat. The DUKE and BESS exchange glances.
Yes. I give you my blessing if you will accept my feelings for Charles Grey. BESS blinks, taken aback. GEORGIANA is nervous. She smile waiting for The DUKE's reaction.

I wasn't sure at first, I thought perhaps it was a dalliance or ... But it isn't. He can make me happy. BESS tries to manage a smile. She darts a look at the DUK who now stands. Suddenly cutlery and crystal jangle. BESS and GEORGIANA start.
(seething with fury) A deal! A deal!! I don't make deals! I'm in charge of it all!! I would call him out! I would challenge him! I would put a bullet in the upstart’s head--!  92 93
William--!
(to BESS) Be quiet! (to GEORGIANA) Are you determined to make me a total laughing stock? A man who cannot sire a son and then a cuckold?
William, Georgiana only asks what we ourselves —
Be quiet, you fool! (to GEORGIANA) Are you his whore?!
... No... but I can't see why you should mind. You have Bess and three boys...
Three boys??? Do you think I can make those bastards my heirs? Well, do you? GEORGIANA and BESS are frightened. GEORGIANA hurries out the room. A moment passes, then the DUKE strides out as w
William...?
GEORGIANA walks fast through the space. She passes a FOOTMAN on the way to her bedroom. The DUKE charges after her. GEORGIANA quickens her pace. BESS follows behind.

GEORGIANA comes into her room, and slams the door behind A few moments later, the door opens. The DUKE enters. He shuts the door. He glares at GEORGIANA. She looks at him. DUKE asks a real question for once.  94 95 96 97 98
You don't know me in the least, do you?
I do. We're a bad match.
I asked but two things when we wed: loyalty and a male heir.
Yes, same as your dogs. The DUKE's eyes flash. He snaps. He grabs her. She tries fight him off. Her dress is torn. They struggle. The DUKE overpowers her.
BESS stands outside the door. We HEAR GEORGIANA SCREAM.
The DUKE pins GEORGIANA onto the bed and tears away at he clothes. We hear the RIP of silk and lace. GEORGIANA screams again. He holds her face tightly between his hand and stares coldly at her.
LITTLE G. and HARRYO stare at the door of their room as t screams continue.
A FOOTMAN stands at attention, trying to remain impassive

BESS hovers at the door as she listens to the struggle an screams inside. She turns and sees CHARLOTTE standing a f feet away, staring at her. BESS moves away from the door, unable to stop what's going on inside.  99 100
(To Charlotte, softly) Come with me. CHARLOTTE stays rooted to the spot.
(Firmer) Charlotte, come with me. BESS takes CHARLOTTE’S arm and hurries her off down the h
GEORGIANA lies on the bed. It's over. Her clothes are torn. Her face is red and wet with tears. The DUKE sits on the side of the bed, panting, used up.

Give me a son and then do what the hell you want, as long as you do it discreetly. Until then you stay here and do as I say. The DUKE gets up and leaves. GEORGIANA's expression is bl dead. The sounds of crowds cheering and clapping fade up the background until we...
SHERIDAN stands before A HUGE CROWD. There is bunting in WHIG colours and banners. The PRESS are out in even great numbers than before.
I give you the winner! Mr Fox! The Man of the People! FOX comes forth to a ROAR of approval. He yells out:

And I give you the weapon! The Duchess of Devonshire! GEORGIANA, still shell-shocked, comes forth to WILD CHEER She succeeds in smiling to the crowd. BESS and the DUKE s together off to the side. They clap and smile, but the st is evident. GREY, unseen near the doorway, watches GEORGIANA taking i the APPLAUSE. Finally, the applause dies.  101
Thank you, all of you, for this reception today. GEORGIANA sees GREY on the sidelines. She glances at the DUKE then turns to slip away. GREY sees this. He follows.
We have won the vote, and now we must win the future! APPLAUSE as GREY exits.
GEORGIANA heads for her coach, well away from the crowd. GREY catches up with her.
We did it. Or should I say you did it. GEORGIANA tries to smile, but she can't. She turns away f GREY. He knows something's wrong.
Georgiana?
(the hardest thing to say) Mr. Grey... I have enjoyed more than I can say the times we've spent together, the talks... GEORGIANA is overcome. She almost breaks down. GREY looks in the eye.
Tell me.
I cannot say what -
Now! GEORGIANA looks at him. She has to do this as she planned
...I have been unfair to you.
What are you talking about?
(trying to be composed) ...I have...indulged in your affections and made it seem my feelings towards you were more than they are in fact. I fear the heat of the election...
Say what you mean!
(looks dead at him) You love me.
Yes!
I do not love you. GREY takes this punch, but his eyes never blink, never wa
You are not speaking what is in your heart.
It is - GREY suddenly stands and strides away, pacing, angry.
(cuts her off) This is a speech, forced upon you-
(overlaps below) No. It's what I've always known to be true!
(overlaps above) -- by those who would destroy our happiness!
(loud, in the clear)
GREY is taken aback by her force and volume.
I was wrong to offer you hope. I was wrong to pretend an affection I do not feel. (MORE)

You have said it yourself, I need to be adored. That is my weakness. GREY looks sick. He turns from her, angry, hurt, unable t find a place to put his feelings. GEORGIANA fights back the tears. We hear CHEERS o.s. GREY turns to her and bows before heading back across the gras the stage. We can hear FOX still speaking.

We have followed our ideas and our ideals, and in the struggle, we have found ourselves! CLOSE ON GEORGIANA as the colour drains from her face. Sh is dying inside but she keeps it all in. She calmly turns and walks to her carriage and is driven away into the bus London street.

AN ELECTION NIGHT PARTY. Music plays in the background. The DUKE waits at the top of the GRAND STAIRCASE, greetin GUESTS. He's dressed for the evening. BESS is with him, also dressed. After a few moments, GEORGIANA appears, walking towards u down the long corridor that leads into the entrance hall. When she reaches the light we see she is dressed to the nines and powdered a deathly white, and has been drinking heavily. The DUKE refuses to register her, but BESS looks across, shocked. GEORGIANA will not meet her eyes, however and walks through into the party.

The rooms have been converted into gaming areas for the evening. It is boisterous and smoky. There are card table and players everywhere. GEORGIANA, wanders through, takin another drink from a passing WAITER. As GEORGIANA goes we pick up details of this decadent society.

Where before it may have seemed glamorous and exciting it now looks uglier and sordid: a place of corruption and addiction, on the edge of collapse. GEORGIANA downs her drink. She passes: gambling at a tabl two fat old men taking snuff; a man in a lewd embrace wit a drunk woman; another man toadying to an important politician. The DUKE appears and looks on, concerned. GEORGIANA takes another drink and leaves the room.
GEORGIANA comes into the dancing area alone. The DUKE and BESS are with a group nearby. GEORGIANA seems to radiate force field that keeps people away from her. But not FOX.

You promised me a dance. Come. Give me my small pleasures. GEORGIANA yields to her old friend. Amid the rest of the GUESTS, GEORGIANA dances around and around with FOX. Her face is hardened, distant - a vision of suppressed anger, frustration and pain. She closes her eyes, her mind drifting to thoughts of GREY. GEORGIANA grabs another drink as they pass a SERVANT. She bumps into SHERIDAN. Drink goes on his jacket.
My dear Duchess, much as I know you love dancing and drinking, I really must advise you to settle for one or the other, for the two are incompatible in the long run.  105

(very drunk) Why, Sheridan, you never were such a spoilsport before! GEORGIANA does a turn and slips. FOX steadies her. She smiles an apology. Then... Suddenly GEORGIANA stumbles. Her WIG falls against a CAND and GOES UP IN FLAMES. DANCERS back away. BESS looks shocked. GEORGIANA SCREAMS as she staggers, hair on fire. DOORS OPEN, SHOUTS, SERVANTS rush about. BESS attempts to knock the WIG off GEORGIANA's head. The DUKE appears in his doorway, none too pleased. He sees th situation. He turns to a FOOTMAN, all efficiency.

Please put out Her Grace's hair. The FOOTMAN splashes water on the wig. HISS and SMOKE. The DUKE looks down at GEORGIANA: she lies sprawled on th polished parquet floor: wig-less, her make-up smeared, he eyes red and glassy.
CLOSE ON a SMALL BOWL with a WHITE HANDKERCHIEF draped ov the top. There are DROPS OF BLOOD on the handkerchief.
Her Grace needs to rest. We see GEORGIANA in bed, pale, washed out, and exhausted. BESS, the DUKE, and MAIDS hover as DR. NEVILLE (62) sets bowl aside.
As long as you follow strict instructions, there should be no impediment to the birth. The DUKE is mystified. BESS looks at GEORGIANA, who shows sign of registering what has been said.
What are you talking about?
The Duchess is pregnant.  106 107 108 109 The DUKE and BESS react. GEORGIANA has no reaction at all

A church stands out against the countryside. There are so of distant bells far off in the distance. A BOY runs into bell tower and rings the bell as hard as he can... In another church in another part of the county, another BOY hears the sound and rings his own the church’s bells. And in another church, bells ring out too...
CLOSE ON - A NAKED NEWBORN BABY being washed by a NURSE. is a boy. In the background the bells continue to ring. I the room are DR. NEVILLE, and MAIDS.
Congratulations, Your Grace. DR NEVILLE bows and makes his way out of the room. As he goes a SERVANT appears.
His Grace wishes to see you.
The DUKE is seated at his desk, a contract out in front o him. HEATON stands and points out where he should sign.
Also there Your Grace...And there... HEATON offers a smile. The DUKE says nothing. He senses GEORGIANA, who is at the library door looking in.
Come. GEORGIANA enters. The DUKE looks to HEATON.  110
Your Grace. As per the terms of His Grace’s inheritance, this is for you. To spend as you wish. HEATON hands her a cheque. GEORGIANA looks at the DUKE wi disdain.
(very sad and dry) Success at last. The DUKE looks away, ashamed. GEORGIANA turns to the door
I too abhor this whole thing. GEORGIANA turns back. The DUKE is now standing.

Yet remove our traditions - separate our estates, sell off the land and the nobility simply ceases to be. Without us England would once again suffer absolute monarchy or descend into absolute anarchy. I don’t wish to see that happen. Do you? GEORGIANA looks at him, then turns and leaves.
The BABY BOY lies in a moving pram. GEORGIANA walks with children. She holds CHARLOTTE by the hand, while LITTLE G and HARRYO look into a pram pushed by a NANNY.
He's so small.
You've been that small yourself.
Not that small. Have I, Mama?
You have, darling. You've all been that small once.
See, I told you.  They continue towards the old FARM HOUSE.
I can't tell that he's a boy at all.
But he is.
But if I can't tell, I fail to see why it's so important. He looks just like the rest of us. GEORGIANA smiles at his innocent view of the world.
